importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Nicolas Sarkozy officially began serving his five-year prison sentence, marking a significant moment in French political history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year sentence implies Sarkozy will serve his jail term through late 2026, making this timeframe critical for understanding the duration and implications of his incarceration.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, has started a five-year jail sentence for criminal conspiracy related to illegal payments from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, marking a historic moment in EU political accountability.
He was found guilty of accepting millions of euros to fund his 2007 election campaign, despite consistently denying the charges.
Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell at La Sante prison, with limited contact and one daily walk.
His lawyers immediately filed a release appeal, which the court has two months to review.
Presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino stated the offences were of 'exceptional gravity,' justifying the prison sentence even with an appeal.
Sarkozy expressed belief in his innocence and said he will take a Bible and 'The Count of Monte Cristo' with him, symbolizing hope and justice.
Dozens of supporters and family members gathered outside his home in protest and in solidarity, reflecting public sentiment about the case.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year prison sentence at La Sante prison in Paris after being convicted of criminal conspiracy for accepting illegal payments from Libyaâ€™s Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign. Despite always denying the charges, the presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offences as of 'exceptional gravity' and upheld the prison term even with a pending appeal. Sarkozy, the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, is currently held in solitary confinement, with limited interaction and one daily walk. His lawyers have filed a release appeal, which the court will review in two months. The case has sparked public outrage and solidarity from supporters, who view the imprisonment as a threat to democracy. The incident also marks a historic moment, as Sarkozy becomes the first French leader since Nazi collaborator Philippe Petain to be imprisoned.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
